sentences: Leonard Niehaus (June 1, 1929 – May 28, 2020) was an American alto saxophonist, composer and arranger on the West Coast jazz scene.
section: N/A

sentences: He played with the Stan Kenton Orchestra and served as one of Kenton's primary staff arrangers.
section: N/A

sentences: He also played with Ray Vasquez and trombonist and Vocalist, Phil Carreon and other jazz bands on the U.S. West Coast.
section: N/A

sentences: Niehaus had a close association as composer and arranging to motion pictures produced by Clint Eastwood.
section: N/A
== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: Education and active years as a musician =
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===
== Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: Niehaus was born in St. Louis, Missouri on June 1, 1929 to Aaron "Père"and Clariss (Weissman) Niehaus.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: His mother was a homemaker.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: His father, a Russian immigrant, was a violinist who played in an orchestra that accompanied silent films in theaters.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: In the mid-1930s, after talking pictures had taken hold, he moved the family to Los Angeles, where he played in Hollywood studio orchestras.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: His sister was a concert pianist.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: His father started him on violin at age seven, then he switched to bassoon.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: At thirteen, Niehaus began alto saxophone and clarinet, about this time he began composing.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: In 1946, after graduation from Roosevelt High School, Niehaus started to study music at Los Angeles City College later earning a music education degree from Los Angeles State College in 1951 as part of the school's first full graduating class.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: Niehaus began his professional career arranging for and playing alto saxophone with Phil Carreón and His Orchestra in the Los Angeles area.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===

sentences: Members of the band included saxophonists Herb Geller, trombonist Ray Vasquez, Herbie Steward, and saxophonist Teddy Edwards.
section: == Life and career == | === Education and active years as a musician ===
== Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: Stan Kenton Orchestra ===
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: After completing college in 1951, Niehaus got his start with the Stan Kenton Orchestra and toured with the band for six months out on the road.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: His association with Kenton would be interrupted as he was drafted into the Army in 1952 and served at Fort Ord in California.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: After being discharged in 1954, he rejoined Kenton for five years as the lead alto saxophonist.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: He composed and arranged extensively for the Kenton band being a feature soloist and having numerous arrangements featured on Kenton's Capitol Records releases.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: He had the longest and most recorded tenure of any of the lead alto players with the group to include such names as Charlie Mariano, Lee Konitz, Gabe Baltazar, or Tony Campise.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: Niehaus left the Kenton orchestra as an instrumentalist in 1959 to pursue music composition in the studios, “I put my horn away and started writing instead.”
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: He continued to serve as a staff arranger for Kenton into the 1960s.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===

sentences: He would go on during that time to write and arrange music for entertainers acts such as the King Sisters, Mel Tormé, Dean Martin, and Carol Burnett.
section: == Life and career == | === Stan Kenton Orchestra ===
== Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: Orchestrating and composing for television and film =
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===
== Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: By the age of 33, in 1962, he began orchestrating for television and film composer Jerry Fielding.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: Niehaus worked with Fielding on approximately seventy TV shows and films like Hogan's Heroes, Charlie’s Angels and McMillan & Wife.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: Films on this list include Straw Dogs (1971), Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia (1974) by Sam Peckinpah, the comedy The Bad News Bears (1976), and the horror film Demon Seed (1977).
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: After Fielding’s death Niehaus came into his own as a leading film composer; he always did his own orchestrating for his scores not using any ghost writers.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: In his film scores, Niehaus never forgot his jazz roots.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: The story of the film City Heat (1984) was set in the 1930s, so he wrote jazz of that period hiring people like altoist Marshal Royal.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: Bill Perkins came in and played like Lester Young; a jazz violinist sounded like Stéphane Grappelli.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===

sentences: There was also a boogie woogie sequence with three pianists Pete Jolly, Mike Land and co-star Clint Eastwood.
section: == Life and career == | === Orchestrating and composing for television and film ===
== Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: Work with Clint Eastwood =
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====
== Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: With Clint Eastwood, Niehaus had probably his most significant professional relationship.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: The two men had first met when serving together in the U.S. Army at Fort Ord during 1952 - 1954.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: Both found they had a passion for jazz music.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: Niehaus had already orchestrated scores for films starring Eastwood like Tightrope (1984), also produced by Eastwood.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: But it was not until Eastwood's eleventh film as director, Pale Rider (1985), that Niehaus actually wrote the first entire score for one of his films.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: Niehaus then wrote the musical scores for the following twelve films up to Blood Work (2002), and orchestrated the music for the next six features that Eastwood completed, from Mystic River (2003) to Gran Torino (2008).
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: Niehaus won the BMI Film & TV Awards for Heartbreak Ridge (1986),  Unforgiven (1992), The Bridges of Madison County (1995), and Space Cowboys (2000).
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: The most substantial collaboration between Niehaus and Eastwood related directly to jazz, was the 1988 biographical film on Charlie Parker, Bird.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====

sentences: Besides a Golden Globe for Eastwood as best director, an Academy Award for best sound and many others, the score by Niehaus was nominated for a BAFTA Award, and won 2nd place at the Los Angeles Film Critics Association Awards, shared between Niehaus and Charlie Parker, due to a production process that had managed to electronically isolate Parker's saxophone solos from the original recordings and backed them with modern stereo recordings.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Work with Clint Eastwood ====
== Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====

sentences: Other awarded film scores =
section: == Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====
== Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====
== Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====

sentences: Lennie Niehaus wrote the music for another jazz related feature, the 1993 TV movie Lush Life, in which Forest Whitaker, who played Charlie Parker in Bird, also starred as a jazz saxophonist.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====

sentences: Niehaus won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Miniseries, Movie, or a Special.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====

sentences: In 2008 he was nominated again for Oprah Winfrey Presents: Mitch Albom's For One More Day.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Other awarded film scores ====

sentences: Further works and educational publishing =
section: == Life and career == | === Further works and educational publishing ===
== Life and career == | === Further works and educational publishing ===

sentences: His work includes Spiritual Jazz Suite, four pieces arranged for brass quartet, three sets of Christmas Jazz suites (4 pieces in each) and a Christmas Jazz Medley arranged for saxophone quartet.
section: == Life and career == | === Further works and educational publishing ===

sentences: His educational publishing includes  a book of classical saxophone duets, a beginning/intermediate/advanced method books for the understanding of jazz technique, and a book of jazz saxophone duets exemplifying jazz styles.
section: == Life and career == | === Further works and educational publishing ===

sentences: After many years of not playing his alto saxophone at all, Niehaus returned to performing, reportedly in top form.
section: == Life and career == | === Further works and educational publishing ===

sentences: He played saxophone as leader of his octet on his album, Sunday Afternoons At The Lighthouse Cafe (2004).
section: == Life and career == | === Further works and educational publishing ===

section: == Life and career == | === Later life and death ===
== Life and career == | === Later life and death ===

sentences: In addition to his film scores and orchestrations, Niehaus spent his final years playing with jazz combos in the Los Angeles area.
section: == Life and career == | === Later life and death ===

sentences: He died in Redlands, California at the age of 90.
section: == Life and career == | === Later life and death ===

sentences: Although a cause of death was not disclosed, his son-in-law said that it was likely heart-related.
section: == Life and career == | === Later life and death ===
